Known as the '''false death cap''', or '''Citron Amanita''', '''''Amanita citrina''''' (previously also known as ''Amanita mappa'') is a [[Basidiomycota|basidiomycotic]] [[mushroom]], one of many in the genus ''[[Amanita]]''. It grows in silicate soil in the summer and autumn months. It bears a pale yellow or sometimes white cap, with white stem, ring and volva. Though it is not poisonous, its similarity to the lethal death cap (''[[Amanita phalloides]]'') precludes its use in cooking.

==Description==
[[File:Amanita.citrina2.-.lindsey.jpg|thumb|left|Closer view of gills and ring of an Amanita citrina from Commanster, Belgium.]]
This mushroom has a fleshy pale yellow, or sometimes white, [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] from {{convert|4|–|10|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} across, covered in irregular patches. The [[gill]]s and flesh are white. There is a large [[Volva (mycology)|volva]] at the base of the {{convert|6|–|8|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} tall stem, which has a clear ring. This mushroom is not eaten, having a smell of [[rapeseed]] or [[potato]]. It is often confused with the related death cap mushroom ''([[Amanita phalloides]])'', hence the name.<ref name = "Ultimatemush">{{cite book| author = P. Jordan & S. Wheeler | year = 2001 | title = The Ultimate Mushroom Book | publisher = Hermes House | ISBN =}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
The false death cap is found in [[deciduous]] and [[coniferous]] woodlands in Autumn in [[Europe]].<ref name = "Ultimatemush"/> It is also found in [[North American]] oak and pine forests.

==Toxicity==
It has been shown that this mushroom contains the [[alpha-amanitin]] toxin.{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} However, the amounts of this toxin were found to be very small and would not cause any adverse effects unless the mushroom was ingested in very large amounts. The biggest danger with this species is its marked similarity to the death cap, which is reason enough to avoid it, even though it is edible.
